title: Rolling - sphere getting up to angular speed

content.question: A solid sphere is initially moving at a constant speed <math alttext=" v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> on a horizontal surface, as shown in the figure. At first, the sphere is sliding without rotating and moves with negligible friction on a smooth section of the surface. The sphere then reaches a rough section of the surface where the coefficient of kinetic friction is <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Î¼</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></math>. Sometime later, the sphere is rolling without slipping on the rough section. The sphere has a mass <math alttext="m sub S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, a radius <math alttext="r sub S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>r</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub></math>, and a rotational inertia about its center <math alttext="I sub S equals two fifths m sub S, end sub, r sub S, end sub, squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub><msup><msub><mi>r</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub><mn>2</mn></msup></math>.
